this is another game that's fallen victim to the f2p model done incorrectly. they use what i can only describe as an extortionist version of f2p. that's honestly the best way i can describe it.   the game is quite expansive, there are a deccent number of maps, a fantastic number of animals to hunt, and a good number of weapons and accessories to use. there's about a dozen maps, 2 dozen or more animals, a dozen guns, and tons of accessories from scents, to tents, to calls, to ammo, scopes, etc. LOTS of content in this game. here's what you have access to as a free player. 1 gun, 2 animals, 2 maps, 1 call. that's it. you can grind the in game currency by hunting those 2 starter animals and then use the currency to buy temprorary licenses to hunt other animals. the grind is unbearable. especially when you factor in the fact that on the free maps, the 2 animals you can hunt are fairly rare. it takes a long time to find a track for either one of those animals.   ok but let's say you're ok with paying money. you take a look at their packages, ranging from a respectable 10 dollars up to 50 bucks. ok fine i don't mind shelling out 10 bucks. but low and behold once you do shell out the 10 bucks you dont get access to anything other then licenses to kill all the animals and access to all the maps. you can't get any new clothes unless you spend money, guns? spend money, ammo? spend money, calls? spend money, tents? spend money. virtually EVERYWHERE you turn you have to spend money.    look the bottomline is, if you're ok with shelling out 100-200$+ for this game, it's a good hunting game with multiplayer features. but understand that at every turn in this game if there's something you need access to to play this game, you have to pay for it.   for comparison, imagine if you were playing league of legends or dota, except you're only given access to 5 hero's, and if you ever want to play new ones without paying money you have to grind out hours and hours of work to get temporary access to a new hero. you can pay but then the game becomes a monthly subscription. and with that in mind this game is NOT worth a monthly subscription. sorry it just plain isn't. you could buy deer hunter for 20 bucks and get nearly the same experience. there are many stand alone hunting games that are comparable to this game and those games dont' require hundreds of dollars to access the full game.   look i know f2p models are great for squeezing money out of excited players. but you're not going to expand your player base by crippling your game, ♥♥♥♥ even in the old days of freeware games they gave you more access to their game then this. you've got less then 10% of this game to try. this game is basically freeware, except with even less access then old DOS freeware games.  as for the recent surge of positive reviews, the dev's of this game made a post in the game's launcher talking about how they saw too many negative reviews of this game. so the players of this game went all white knight and trie dto skew the reviews by writing positive reviews. they're probably die hard fans of the game and can't see past their love of the game to give you a serious look at the game's flaws. frankly it's biggest flaw is the pay model. you cannot say that the pay model should be judged seperately of the gameplay, not when the gameplay is so closely tied to the pay model. if i didn't know better, i would have thought the game DLC quest was a parody of this game. that's how bad the pay model is.
It's basically not free... The game is sort of built up on micro-transactions. If you want to play it for free you wont going to be playing the way you thought.

What do you do in this game? You walk for 95% of the time, but some times, you're lucky and find deers. Taking aim, firing and hitting that deer you've tracked down for so long, right through its lungs, and then harvesting its body, is the best feeling in the world. All that walking is worth it. Nothing beats the thrill of spotting a deer with a huge pair of antlers after such a long time of tracking it down. Walking around is peaceful and exciting. It isn't free to play though. The only thing you can hunt unless you pay is mule deer. I got to maybe 10 mule deer kills before I couldn't take it anymore, and so I bought 3 months of premium for 9.99 USD (or around 7€) and 1000em$ so I could buy myself a good weapon and rifle scope, and that in total cost around 15€.  I wouldn't say this is a game for everyone, but it sure gives me a super hard-on. Shooting animals is so rewarding, and the long walk isn't bad. It's peaceful and filled with excitement. You almost get a heart attack when you know you're really close, so you're looking everywhere, and then a moose roars from like 10 meters away. It's just way more exciting than you'd think. This game isn't really free to play though, you really have to pay a little, but it's not much; still less than normal games usually cost.

If you want a realistic hunting simulator, then this is the game for you. If you want cabela's kill every animal you see, go get a wii. But for people who actually want realism in their games (me being one of them, to an extent) this game is perfect. In real life, you need a license to hunt certain animals, and I am pretty sure in real life said licenses are temporary (maybe per season I dunno) and this game simulates that and MUCH more. The fact is, I got bored of the game on my first day, mainly because I was in a pissy mood and couldn't find any thing to hunt. on the second day, in a much better mood, I found a multitude of animal tracks. I was so happy, so I tracked it down for about 20 minutes. I found a Mule Deer in a field, lined up a shot, and killed it with a shot to the lungs. I was so happy, having tracked down and shot my prey much like a real hunter. So if you like to hunt for the thrill of finally getting that kill you've been tracking all day? This is the game for you. I definitely suggest this to any hunting enthusiasts who happen to be looking for something that hits closer to home than other hunting 'Simulators' especially since you definitely know you achieved something when you start to unlock extra perks (not CoD perks, perks like tools, weapons, extra access basically.) it really makes all your hard work show. It is also pretty good for if you want to just sit down, and walk around taking in the beautifully built environments in which you can hunt. There are even collectibles you can collect, recreational activities like shooting on the Firing Range, Skee Shooting, Hiking, and there might be more to come.

You know, I used to play this game before it came on steam. I've come back to the game on and off for years, because as far as hunting games go, this really is the best game out there. Now, is it action filled? Not really, this game really does a dam decent job of simulating hunting, but what that means is, theres a whole lot of killing nothing. You can spend hours in this game without a kill. But on the flipside, when you get the kill, it's insanely rewarding. Now everyone here is complaining about the business model, which I can't entirely blame them. On the flipside though, this is the same business model the game has had for years, and simply, if you actually do enjoy the game, you'll be willing to pay the money. Does that make it any less ridiculous? No. But this game has been around for years, and the makers keep adding more and more to it, so if paying the money supports the game you enjoy, I say pay it.  Now the payment and a loss of interest has resulted in me not playing this game in quite some time, but the free membership gives you exactly what you need to figure out if you're willing to pay. Hunt some whitetail, get a few kills, if you like it, if you feel like the reward outweighed the boredom and learning curve, then drop some cash. In the end, give the game a whirl, it's a niche game for a niche community, but if you find out you're part of that niche, you won't find a better hunting game honestly.

theHunter claims to be a free to play game, however upon creating an account you are only allowed to hunt the mule deer with the starter rifle. This is slightly misleading calling the game free to play, because in order to get any sort of fun gameplay out of theHunter you need to buy membership (Unlocks all animals) and on top of that pay for em$ (The premium currency) to buy guns, camo etc.  This game is not really for the 'free player', although if you have a small amount of money ($20-$30USD) you can buy the camo you want, the membership ($10USD for three months) and a gun of your choice.  If you have the money and you enjoy hunting simulators I highly recommend this game to anybody who would be willing to invest a small amount of money into such a detailed and well made game.  Now, the community. The community is 98% friendly when you meet players online, however there is those few 'odd-balls' out there. Most players who have played the game for a while will be willing to help the newbies learn the ropes of theHunter, as long as you are respectful of their hunt. (Not running up to them without asking etc.) The relationship between theHunter team and the community is probably one of the strongest I have seen. They are constantly asking the community to offer feedback and way to improve the game.

This game is by far the greatest hunting simulation I have ever seen. The hunting, and tracking tactics are great. You can get the same feeling in this game, as you can in the real world, stalking up to your favorite ridge that you spent all year scouting for the perfect deer trail to sit on. Unfortunatly, this is a negitive yet positive review. Not for the game, but for the micro transactions that rival Zynga. EA atleast has some compassion when it deals with micro transactions. To enjoy any aspect of other than hunting mule deer and rabbit you need to buy a license. Which is fine, the game is free after all. So, paying 31.99 for 6 months of play time seemed fine to me at first. Until I wanted to pack up and send it to the nearest duck pond to slay some Mallards. Come to find out, I needed to purchase a duck call, and a duck decoy to even have a chance at landing a duck. So, I proceed to the store, hopeing I could buy the items with in-game currency. Sadly, to purchase additional items you need to either succumb yourself filling out third party surveys that fill your e-mail with spam by the minute, and probably a cyber stalker. Or you pay for items. So after paying 32 dollars for this truely amazing game, I have to spend another 5 dollars just to get a chance at some ducks. Not to mention if I wanted to get bear bait, lures, scent covers.    If you are fine with paying around 150 dollars to unlock everything in this game to aid you in your hunts, than by all means. Buy it, it's a wonderful game.

Although the this game tries to pull every dollar out of your pocket that it possibly can, it is worth spending a little bit on. It has quality gameplay for what I would say is a reasonable price. Sure, it seems like $30 is a lot to put up for a game that is free to play, but if you're really into this type of game it will be worth it.   For an initial $15 (basic membership) you get licenses and unlimited ammo for three months and a shotgun and pistol. With this and your already owned .243 you can basically kill anything if you take the time, but putting just a little more money into it could make it even better. For example. I had been gifted a membership by someone I met in game which expanded my ability greatly, and with that $15 membership plus $15 for the .30-06 rifle and a scope I had three months of animal killing fun. The guns included with the $15 membership plus almost any rifle you can choose from will open a door to hunting any animal in the game.  I can promise anyone who is really interested in or already into hunting that they will like this game if they put a little money into it.  I would also like to mention to everyone who has said that they go out and find nothing, you are either terrible at the game or impatient because you can easily find a mule deer in about 20 minutes.

This game is by far the greatest hunting simulation I have ever seen. The hunting, and tracking tactics are great. You can get the same feeling in this game, as you can in the real world, stalking up to your favorite ridge that you spent all year scouting for the perfect deer trail to sit on. Unfortunatly, this is a negitive yet positive review. Not for the game, but for the micro transactions that rival Zynga. EA atleast has some compassion when it deals with micro transactions. To enjoy any aspect of other than hunting mule deer and rabbit you need to buy a license. Which is fine, the game is free after all. So, paying 31.99 for 6 months of play time seemed fine to me at first. Until I wanted to pack up and send it to the nearest duck pond to slay some Mallards. Come to find out, I needed to purchase a duck call, and a duck decoy to even have a chance at landing a duck. So, I proceed to the store, hopeing I could buy the items with in-game currency. Sadly, to purchase additional items you need to either succumb yourself filling out third party surveys that fill your e-mail with spam by the minute, and probably a cyber stalker. Or you pay for items. So after paying 32 dollars for this truely amazing game, I have to spend another 5 dollars just to get a chance at some ducks. Not to mention if I wanted to get bear bait, lures, scent covers.    If you are fine with paying around 150 dollars to unlock everything in this game to aid you in your hunts, than by all means. Buy it, it's a wonderful game.

Probably not the worst realistic hunting game. But not the best either unfourtantly...  Can this be declared a F2P???  The Hunter isn't bad in-terms of hunting at all, sense the game is diffently realistic. So realistic you need hunting licences just to hunt any of the games extra animals. Now I know what your thinking that sounds pretty good actually. But here's the catch you need to pay for certain animals to hunt. Which woulden't be so bad if you earned your hunting licences instead, or if you could hunt all the animals in one certain area. Unfourtantly that's not the case for this hunting simulater. You need to pay real money in order to hunt the extra animals that the game features. Not only that each animal requires its own licence to hunt. There's only two animals that can be hunted if you want to actually play it freely. Mule Deer and small cotton tail rabbits. However even with the extra rabbits you can't kill them. You need another weapon and since the game doesn't just give it to you. Than your stuck with mule deer.  Is it good atleast?  To be honest its not bad. But I only wished it had more to offer for anyone who actually loves to play these certain games.  I would recommend it just to someone who really loves hunting simulaters. Other than that it's not that special.  If you got the idea this game is a cash cow not a F2P  I'm going to extend this review to say its been nearly 4 years since this games release and its still the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ cash cow.
